definitions.definition: to allow something to fall by accident; to fall by accident
definitions.sensetop: drop somethingdrop something + adv./prep.drop to somethingdrop + adj.

examples.text: Be careful not to drop that plate.
I **accidentally dropped** my glasses into the water.
The climber slipped and dropped to his death.
His arms dropped limply to his sides.
Her mouth dropped open in disbelief.
He saw Emma and promptly dropped his tray of drinks.
He slowly dropped to the floor.
Her heart dropped like a stone at this news.

definitions.definition: to make something fall deliberately; to let yourself fall

examples.text: You can never be sure whether the planes will be **dropping bombs** or food parcels.
Medical supplies are being dropped into the stricken area.
She lifted the bag then dropped it down again.
He dropped his trousers *(= undid them and let them fall)*.
He dropped his pants.
Catch me when I drop.
I dropped to my knees beside her.
The plane came straight in, dropping down to land in a field.
He dropped lightly down onto the lawn beneath.
The cheese drops onto a conveyor underneath.
He casually drops the latest buzzwords into the conversation.

definitions.definition: to fall down or be no longer able to stand because you are extremely tired

examples.text: I feel **ready to drop**.
She expects everyone to work till they drop.
He staggered in and dropped into a chair.

definitions.definition: to become or make something weaker, lower or less
definitions.sensetop: drop to somethingdrop by somethingdrop in something (by something)drop against somethingdrop something

examples.text: The **temperature** has **dropped** considerably.
At last the wind dropped.
Error rates have **dropped dramatically**.
His voice dropped to a whisper.
The Dutch team have dropped to fifth place.
The **price** of shares **dropped** by 14p.
Shares **dropped in price** by 14p.
The dollar **dropped sharply** against the euro.
You must drop your speed in built-up areas.
The number of children in the class has dropped from 25 to 18.
The price of oil has dropped significantly.
The temperature rarely drops below 30°C.
Sales are likely to drop further.
Processing costs dropped 30 per cent.
The baby's heart rate had dropped.

definitions.definition: to fail to win something

examples.text: It's a long time since we dropped a game.
They didn't drop any points until halfway through the season.
She dropped the second set but came back to win the match.
He **dropped his serve ***(= failed to win games in which it was his turn to hit the ball first)* twice in the first set.

definitions.definition: to look down

examples.text: Her eyes dropped to her lap.
He smiled and let his eyes drop again.

definitions.definition: to slope steeply downwards

examples.text: In front of them the valley dropped sharply away from the road.
The land dropped steeply away into a small valley.

definitions.definition: to stop so that somebody can get out of a car, etc.; to deliver or leave something in a particular place, especially on the way to somewhere else
definitions.sensetop: drop somebody/somethingdrop somebody/something offdrop something + adv./prep.

examples.text: Can you drop me near the bank?
You left your jacket, but I can drop it off on my way to work tomorrow.
Just drop it in the mail when you have time.

definitions.definition: to send a short letter or email to somebody
definitions.sensetop: drop somebody a line/a note/an email

examples.text: Drop me a line when you get there.
Don't hesitate to drop me an email or give me a call.

definitions.definition: to put some text, an icon, etc. into a file, folder or place on a computer screen, using the mouse

examples.text: You can easily **drag and drop** files onto your memory stick.

definitions.definition: to leave somebody/something out by accident or deliberately

examples.text: She's been dropped from the team because of injury.
He spoke with a cockney accent and **dropped his aitches** *(= did not pronounce the letter ‘h’ at the start of words)*.
He was unceremoniously dropped by his record label.

definitions.definition: to stop seeing somebody socially

examples.text: She's dropped most of her old friends.

definitions.definition: to stop doing or discussing something; to not continue with something

examples.text: I dropped German *(= stopped studying it)* when I was 14.
**Drop everything** and come at once!
Look, can we just **drop it** *(= stop talking about it)*?
I think we'd better drop the subject.
The police decided to **drop the charges** against her.
Let's drop the formalities—please call me Mike.
Both countries have agreed to drop border controls.
He suddenly dropped his habitual banter.
The formal grade of Geologist was dropped in favour of Scientific Officer.
When nobody volunteered, the idea was finally dropped altogether.

definitions.definition: to say or do something in order to show somebody, in an indirect way, what you are thinking
to be made available to the public

examples.text: A new episode drops every Monday.

definitions.definition: to let a stitch go off the needle
people stop buying or using the products of a particular industry

examples.text: The bottom has fallen out of the travel market.

definitions.definition: to die or become ill and fall down in very large numbers

examples.text: People were dropping like flies in the intense heat.

definitions.definition: to tell the police or people in authority that somebody has done something wrong

examples.text: If he finds out who dropped the dime on him, they're in trouble.
I'm worried if I drop a dime on them, they'll get fired, which I don't think they really deserve.

definitions.definition: to make a mistake and cause something that you are responsible for to fail

examples.text: Let’s not drop the ball on this.

definitions.definition: to say something that offends or embarrasses somebody, although you did not intend to
to suddenly not be able to think clearly; to act in a stupid way because you have lost control over yourself
to die suddenly and unexpectedly
used to tell somebody, rudely, to stop annoying you, interfering, etc.
to stop being careful and preparing yourself for possible danger or difficulty

examples.text: You can never drop your guard with a two-year-old.
Even when he's winning, he never drops his guard.

definitions.definition: to put somebody in an embarrassing situation, especially by telling a secret that you should not have told
to make something the responsibility of another person

examples.text: They dropped the problem firmly back in my lap.

definitions.definition: to mention famous people you know or have met in order to impress others

examples.text: She found him rather irritating to talk to; all he did was drop names.

definitions.definition: somebody has the opportunity to do something pleasant without having made any effort

examples.text: My dream job just fell into my lap.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody suddenly looked surprised, shocked or disappointed
to do or say nothing more about somebody/something

examples.text: I suggest we let the matter drop.

definitions.definition: to mention somebody/something in a conversation, by accident or as if by accident

examples.text: He **let it drop that** the prime minister was a close friend of his.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody has finally understood or realized something that they had not understood or realized before

examples.text: I had to explain the joke to her a couple of times before the penny dropped.

definitions.definition: it was extremely quiet

examples.text: The audience was so quiet you could have heard a pin drop.

wordOrigin: Old English dropa (noun), droppian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to German Tropfen ‘a drop’, tropfen ‘to drip’, also to drip and droop.
